posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
I hope everyone has had a great start to the school year! This summer, Team 9312 has developed a new swerve learning minibot called TurdSwerve that we aim to share with the FRC community.

TurdSwerve is a compact, 3D-printed swerve chassis designed as an off-season bot for teams transitioning to swerve drive or for training rookies and refining code. It works with Neos, Falcons, or Kraken motors, with plans for CIM support soon. It uses a standard electronics base like a full swerve drive but replaces costly COTS pods with 3D-printed PLA ones, costing around $40 USD to build using spare parts. The gearing is easy to swap in under two minutes, minimizing the number of screws needed—a small price to pay for programmer convenience!

The robot is compact, measuring as small as 15 inches wide, and built for ease of use. A single programmer can use it as a complete, all-in-one learning tool. Teams can import existing swerve codebases or TunerX-generated code and adjust settings to suit TurdSwerve specifications for competition coding.

NERDSwerve, an upgraded version of TurdSwerve, features a more durable pod design with a budget-friendly swerve bearing, all while keeping costs under $100 per robot. The original TurdSwerve design remains available for teams looking to save money.

We've released several tutorials covering Onshape configurations, robot assembly, and a soon-to-be-released programming guide for NERDSwerve. These resources are available on Team 9312’s YouTube channel and the newly launched NERDSwerve website.

Check out these materials if they could benefit your team!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: It's super cool; definitely, we're going to make one.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: It seems like you're driving it pretty hard in the demo video. How long does it last? Is it something you can substantially drive? I'm thinking about something like an alpha bot or off-season drive practice.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: That is actually only around 50% speed. It is using a full FRC battery and the Krakens are really overpowered for the 35 lb robot. Driving around at that speed usually lasts for 30-40 minutes before we start to brown out. A 2-pod robot would likely last longer. If you're planning on using it for drive practice, you will have to keep in mind that it is so small and much easier to drive than a full robot. You could mount it to a bigger main plate if you want to make it full size. Bumpers might be necessary too. As for longevity, we have been driving that particular robot for around 20 hours and taken it to a few outreach events, and we haven't had any issues. The pod gearing is easily replaceable though and can be fixed very easily if there are any problems.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: This looks really great! It’s also a great advertisement for lightweighting.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
That’s impressive! I’m more interested in understanding how long the modules last compared to the amount of driving time they provide.

I wonder if the gears wear out over time and how impacts affect their performance. Additionally, I’d like to know the weight capacity of these modules.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: To determine how long it lasts before needing to replace gears or other parts, consider specifying the type of equipment, such as a car, machine, or device, as this affects maintenance intervals. Regular maintenance schedules vary by model and usage, so providing more details will help offer a more accurate answer.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
We have driven it for around 20 hours and haven’t encountered any issues. While we haven’t subjected it to the rigorous stress of competitive driving, I can already feel some wear developing in the drive gears. This suggests that another 5-10 hours of driving will likely necessitate replacing them.

Our baseplate is made from MDF, and we recommend not exceeding the current weight of 35 lbs with additional components. Using aluminum or mounting it onto aluminum tubing could allow the system to support a full 125 lbs safely. However, if you opt to widen the baseplate, it may require strengthening the material accordingly.
Will there be a BOM for the four-module version?

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: We have just updated the sheet, sorry about that.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: It appears the NERDSwerve BOM includes lock nuts, whereas the CAD details indicate areas where the nuts are excessively tall and are all jam nuts.
Hi, is the CIM option still in the plans? This could reduce the expense almost to zero for our team, which is rather enticing. In either case, thanks for sharing all this!

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: I believe the jam nuts are only needed for the extra electronics deck supports with a 4-pod & horizontal battery configuration. However, they are redundant, so I forgot to include them in the BOM. If you don’t have jam nuts available, you can skip the corner stilts. There shouldn’t be any other instances where jam nuts are necessary. The CAD nuts resemble jam nuts because it was simpler to use Onshape nuts, which also happen to be jam nuts.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
Yes, there are still CIMs and MiniCIM options available in the CAD. The pod design is identical to the Neo design, but the CIM is slightly wider, causing approximately 1/16 inch of interference when mounted. This should likely be fine, though.

We haven't tested the design with CIMs, so we don't have any example code. Adjusting the configuration from the Neo example code shouldn't be too difficult, however.

While using CIMs is technically feasible, I strongly recommend using a brushless motor instead. This is because the lack of built-in encoders in CIMs makes implementing odometry impossible, which can hinder autonomous programming efforts. If you happen to have extra CIMs on hand, NERDSwerve could still be useful for vision and teleop programming development. In that case, it might still be worth trying.
Thanks! Much appreciated.

posts.name: 3061 Open Alliance Coordinator
posts.cooked: To determine how long it takes to print all swerve modules, we must consider the complexity of the task and the resources available. Additionally, enhancing swerve modules to match the competitiveness of metal swerves may require innovative design modifications and advanced manufacturing techniques. This development could significantly benefit emerging teams aiming to excel in their respective fields.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: On our Bambulab X1C printer, it takes about 48 hours to print 4 pods using PLA. The swerve pods, though functionally similar to metal swerves, may face durability issues when used on a 120-lb robot. In our testing, the forks held up well under driving and collision stress, but the gears began to show wear after 20 hours of high-load operation. Using PA-CF or a different, stronger material could potentially allow more reliable performance on a competition robot.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Teams have tried implementing full 3dp, but as far as I know, all attempts have failed, primarily due to gearing issues. It doesn’t seem worthwhile investing time into competition bots for this purpose.

What updates on the wheel hardness? From your photos, it seems you tried 50A wheels, but many of them are 35A.  

Since dually wheels cost around $15, we thought 50A would offer better durability. Not urgent, just curious—hope your build is going well!

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: Yes, we've seen that the 35A wheels wear quickly but provide more traction. If you're not looking for maximum acceleration, the 50A wheels would be a better choice.

data.title: Introducing NERDSwerve: A Miniature, 3D-Printed Swerve Learning Chassis
data.fancy_title: Introducing NERDSwerve: A Miniature, 3D-Printed Swerve Learning Chassis
